Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2020.11.01]NuGetGallery of dev into master" (#8308) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Dropping the narration completely for absent signature and deprecation information" (#8309) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Another take on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8196 (Previous attempt: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8287)

The expectation actually was that empty cells are not read completely by a narrator, instead of producing an explanation regarding why the cell is empty.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1][ARIA]Some status/alert messages are not being read out." (#8284) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Concerning the following:
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1061326
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1061322
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1069948

Fixes  need to be made for the following pages/scenarios:
1. Copy for install instructions on package details page
Steps to Reproduce :
    1. Launch application using provided URL.(https://www.nuget.org/)
    2. Navigated to Home page
    3. Search for a key term (say “json”)
    4. Look at the package search results and select any package.
    5. Navigate till "Package Manager" and select it.
    6. Start Narrator and navigate till "Copy" control.
    7. Hit enter on the "Copy" control and observe the announcement by screen reader.
2. API Key Generation success message
Steps to Reproduce :
    1. Launch application using provided URL.(https://www.nuget.org/)
    2. Navigated to Home page
    3. Click on “Sign in” option (top right) and click on “Sign in with Microsoft” button
    4. Sign in using MSA on the common Microsoft sign-in page
    5. Go to “API Keys” from the context menu (top left menu dropdown).
    6. Navigate till "Create Control" and expand it.
    7. Fill all the data in the editing fields.
    8. Start Narrator, click on the "Create" button and observe the announcement by screen reader.
3. Deprecation dialog status messages
Repro Steps:​ Note Same issue was observed on "GitHub Usage" page
    1. Start Screen Reader. Hit the URL "https://www.nuget.org" and sign in with valid credentials​
    2. Tab till "Sign In" link in the top navigation and press enter​
    3. Tab till "Sign in with Microsoft" button and press enter​
    4. Select valid user id and press enter​
    5. Enter any Username, tab till "Register" button and press enter​
    6. Tab till the user menu button and press enter to expand it. Select "Manage Packages" and press enter​
    7. Tab till "Published Packages", expand it and select any existing package.(If no packages are available, add a new package)​
    8. Tab till "Manage Package" link under "Info" and press enter​
    9. Tab till "Deprecation" section and press enter to expand it​
    10. Tab till "Select reason(s)" and uncheck all the check boxes. A status message will be displayed on the screen
    11. Check if the screen reader is reading the status message​

Notes:
All of these are likely missing aria-live regions describing them. Including an aria-live and role to the respective elements that need to be read out should be sufficient. See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8238 for an example of a fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][Reflow]links like 'asp.netcore' and the other links are missing when we resize the page to 150% and 175 %" (#8186) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184498
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Zoom the page to 150%
    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till search box, type "JSON" and press enter
    Check whether all the links are clearly visible without any content loss or not

## Actual Results:

Links like 'asp.netcore' and the other links are missing when we resize the page to 150%
   
## Expected Results:
All the links in the page should be clearly visible without any content loss when the page is resized
## User Impact:
User with low vision who need to zoom the page, may face difficultly in understanding, if the content in the page is not clearly visible.

## Notes
The row that contains the download counts, last updated, and tags will cut off with ellipses when the page width is not sufficient to contain all the information. The recommendation here is probably to make it wrap. Note that this occurs even without resizing on packages that contain a lot of tags (see Microsoft.IdentityModel.JsonWebTokens)

Closed issue "No keyboard gestures to edit the sources in the NuGet Package Manager Options window. " (#9262) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Affected Branch: 
Affected Build: 
Affected Product Language: 

Steps to reproduce:

Go to the Available Package Sources view. 

Use the arrow keys to navigate through the list of sources. When getting to the bottom source, you can navigate to the edit source section. There is no gesture to allows you to change the first n-1 sources. 

This has always been a problem (since 14.x)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "``dotnet nuget push *.nupkg`` doesn't push more than one file" (#4393) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
see also https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/5436

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): dotnet (on Linux)

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): seems RC4 (I have no idea to confirm it)

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 1.0.0-rc4-004598

VS version (if appropriate):NA

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):RHEL 7.3

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:No. 

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Install dotnet SDK daily build package
2. locate 2 different nupkg files
3. set up NuGet Server and API key as you can push nupkg to NuGet Server
4. run ``dotnet nuget push *.nupkg``
5. Only one nupkg file is uploaded.

## Other suggested things

I expect I can push all the nupkg files.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/core/preview3/tools/dotnet-nuget-push

```
$  /opt/dotnet/dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-rc4-004598)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.0.0-rc4-004598
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  1dfee9ead8

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     rhel
 OS Version:  7.3
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         rhel.7.2-x64
 Base Path:   /opt/dotnet/sdk/1.0.0-rc4-004598
```


### Verbose Logs

```
$ ls
libuv.1.9.1.nupkg  Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebUtilities.1.0.0.nupkg
$  /opt/dotnet/dotnet nuget -v Verbose push *  -k <NuGetKey> -s <NuGetServer>
trace: NuGet Command Line Version: 4.0.0.0
info : Pushing libuv.1.9.1.nupkg to '<NuGetServer>'...
info :   PUT <NuGetServer>
info :   Created <NuGetServer> 3215ms
info : Your package was pushed.
```

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!
No need sample project.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Eliminate code redundancy in XmlUtility.cs" (#9091) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While working on a ADO task observed that `XmlUtility` class is coded in 4 different places in NuGet client code. Good to remove code redundancy as part of engineering improvements work. 

$\NuGet.Client\src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.PackageManagement\Utility\XmlUtility.cs
$\NuGet.Client\src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.VisualStudio.Implementation\Utility\XmlUtility.cs
$\NuGet.Client\src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.Configuration\Utility\XmlUtility.cs
$\NuGet.Client\src\NuGet.Core\NuGet.Packaging\PackageCreation\Utility\XmlUtility.cs

/cc @aortiz-msft

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Prepare demo of NuGet RPS tests and obtained results" (#10146) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "props file of nuget VC++ (native) package is not added to ExtensionSettings import group" (#10125) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/1002251/props-file-of-nuget-vc-native-package-is-not-added.html)._ --- If I add a nuget package to a VC++ project (vcxproj), the props file from packages build\native folder is not added to the ``. Instead the import is placed at the beginnig of the project file. The targets file instead is correctly added to the ``. The positioning of build customizations is defined here: [ExtensionSettings ImportGroup element](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/reference/vcxproj-file-structure?view=vs-2019#extensionsettings-importgroup-element). Thank you for fixing this. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 4/23/2020, 00:43 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### kapenaga [MSFT] on 5/5/2020, 05:54 PM:

Unable to reproduce this issue on the following installation of Visual Studio. Can you please upload a sample project to reproduce this issue?

Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2019
Version 16.3.10
VisualStudio.16.Release/16.3.10+29519.87

#### Jojakim Stahl on 5/11/2020, 03:15 AM:

Attached I sent you an example for this. The project history is included, you can see how it evolves in the git log.

What I did:

  1. Create a new VC++ Console App
  2. Create a new Sample package with props and targets file (see in folder SamplePackage)
  3. Build the sample package with "nuget pack"
  4. Add the SamplePackage folder to the package sources in Visual Studio
  5. Add the Package "Sample" to the Console App project. That inserts the import of the props file as the first line of the vcxproj file.

consoleapplication3.zip

Hope this helps to track down the problem.

#### Feedback Bot on 5/18/2020, 09:10 AM:

Thank you for sharing your feedback! Our teams prioritize action on product issues with broad customer impact. See details at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/report-a-problem?view=vs-2019#faq. In case you need answers to common questions or need assisted support, be sure to use https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/support/. We’ll keep you posted on any updates to this feedback.

#### Feedback Bot on 5/18/2020, 09:10 AM:

This issue is currently being investigated. Our team will get back to you if either more information is needed, a workaround is available, or the issue is resolved.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Tabbing through PMUI in the reverse should mirror forward direction" (#10234) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Once you Shift+Tab to the TabControl, you can no longer Shift+Tab to return to the previously focused control.
Tab allows you to cycle through controls indefinitely.
/cc: @dominoFire  @rrelyea 

**Bug: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1241745**

Environment Details:​
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview
Version 16.8 Preview 6.0
OS Details:
Windows 10 Enterprise
Version : 20H2
Build: 19042.572

### Repro Steps:​
1. Open Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview (Version 16.8.0 Preview 6.0)
2. Create a new "Grpc" project
3. Tab till “Solution Explorer” and open "Context Menu".
4. Navigate to "Manage Nuget Packages for Solution" and press enter on it.
5. Navigate to "Update"  tab using arrow key.
6. Search for "gRPC" packages.
7. Tab to all controls and navigate to "Update" tab from "Dependencies" tree view.
8. Navigate to "Dependencies" from "Update" tab using "Shift + Tab".
9. Verify whether user is able to navigate or not.

### Actual Result:​
 Unable to navigate to "Dependencies" tree view item from "Update" tab while shift tabbing.
 Focus is staying on "Update" tab only.

### Expected Result:​
User should be able to navigate to "Dependencies" tree view item from "Update" tab while shift tabbing.

### User Impact:​

Keyboard users find difficulty in navigating to all controls if few controls are not navigable using "Shift + Tab" 

MAS Reference:
MAS 2.4.3 – Focus Order

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe.
